This is a special moment to be here.Because

    • Sweden - SOCKSSS found in Japan the perfect customer and business partner

      https://policy.trade.ec.europa.eu/eu-trade-relationships-...

      The EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement eliminates tariffs on socks, giving this Swedish firm the chance to be competitive in a market with huge potential for fashion and design. 

    • SUSTAINABLE FASHION APPLIED TO THE SEA

      https://maritime-forum.ec.europa.eu/node/7754_en

      Sustainable Fashion and the Sea: A Cross-Disciplinary Project Each year, our school carries out a sustainability project based on a research question that guides us toward taking action to improve our environment and deepen our understanding of the sea. This year, our guiding question was: Are the sports t-shirts provided by our city council sustainable? After analysis, we discovered that all these shirts are made of polyester—a synthetic fiber. We then examined sand samples from our local beach and, alarmingly, found traces of polyester microfibers. This discovery led us to raise awareness within our school community about the environmental impact of synthetic textiles. We conducted laboratory experiments to study microplastic pollution and developed classroom workshops so students of all ages could replicate and understand the issue. Our project went beyond the classroom. During our neighborhood festival, we set up an educational stand to inform the public, and we even presented our findings and proposals to the mayor of our city. We advocated for reducing the production of synthetic sportswear and suggested more sustainable alternatives. As part of our methodology, students design and lead practical experiments and workshops for younger peers. We also joined the Pirates Against Plastic program and participated in a clean-up of the Llobregat riverbank to better understand how plastics move from land to sea. Additionally, we contacted sustainable textile companies like Guppyfriend and Cora Ball by writing letters in English. These companies produce tools to capture microplastics during laundry before they reach the water system and eventually the sea. This is a truly interdisciplinary project involving biology, technology, art, mathematics, social studies, physical education, and languages. Through real-world engagement, science, and communication, our students are becoming agents of change for a more sustainable future.

    • For Our Planet Award

      https://environment.ec.europa.eu/topics/nature-and-biodiv...

Our project went beyond the classroom. We advocated for reducing the production of synthetic sportswear and suggested more sustainable alternatives. This is a truly interdisciplinary project involving biology, technology, art, mathematics, social studies, physical education, and languages.     • SUSTAINABLE FASHION APPLIED TO THE SEA

      https://maritime-forum.ec.europa.eu/node/7754_en

      Sustainable Fashion and the Sea: A Cross-Disciplinary Project Each year, our school carries out a sustainability project based on a research question that guides us toward taking action to improve our environment and deepen our understanding of the sea. This year, our guiding question was: Are the sports t-shirts provided by our city council sustainable? After analysis, we discovered that all these shirts are made of polyester—a synthetic fiber. We then examined sand samples from our local beach and, alarmingly, found traces of polyester microfibers. This discovery led us to raise awareness within our school community about the environmental impact of synthetic textiles. We conducted laboratory experiments to study microplastic pollution and developed classroom workshops so students of all ages could replicate and understand the issue. Our project went beyond the classroom. During our neighborhood festival, we set up an educational stand to inform the public, and we even presented our findings and proposals to the mayor of our city. We advocated for reducing the production of synthetic sportswear and suggested more sustainable alternatives. As part of our methodology, students design and lead practical experiments and workshops for younger peers. We also joined the Pirates Against Plastic program and participated in a clean-up of the Llobregat riverbank to better understand how plastics move from land to sea. Additionally, we contacted sustainable textile companies like Guppyfriend and Cora Ball by writing letters in English. These companies produce tools to capture microplastics during laundry before they reach the water system and eventually the sea. This is a truly interdisciplinary project involving biology, technology, art, mathematics, social studies, physical education, and languages. Through real-world engagement, science, and communication, our students are becoming agents of change for a more sustainable future.

      ASKET is an online-only menswear brand founded with the mission to free wardrobe essentials from fashion and bring them back to basics.

    • Commissioner Roswall's speech at the Global Fashion Summit, 'From Barriers to Bridges'

      https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/spe...

      Good morning, Thank you for inviting me to speak at this year's Global Fashion Summit.I'm especially glad to be back in Copenhagen—a city I know well from my time as Minister for Nordic Affairs.And I look forward to returning many times later this year, when Denmark holds the EU Council Presidency. This is a special moment to be here.Because

    • Sweden - SOCKSSS found in Japan the perfect customer and business partner

      https://policy.trade.ec.europa.eu/eu-trade-relationships-...

      The EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement eliminates tariffs on socks, giving this Swedish firm the chance to be competitive in a market with huge potential for fashion and design. 

    • SUSTAINABLE FASHION APPLIED TO THE SEA

      https://maritime-forum.ec.europa.eu/node/7754_en

      Sustainable Fashion and the Sea: A Cross-Disciplinary Project Each year, our school carries out a sustainability project based on a research question that guides us toward taking action to improve our environment and deepen our understanding of the sea. This year, our guiding question was: Are the sports t-shirts provided by our city council sustainable? After analysis, we discovered that all these shirts are made of polyester—a synthetic fiber. We then examined sand samples from our local beach and, alarmingly, found traces of polyester microfibers. This discovery led us to raise awareness within our school community about the environmental impact of synthetic textiles. We conducted laboratory experiments to study microplastic pollution and developed classroom workshops so students of all ages could replicate and understand the issue. Our project went beyond the classroom. During our neighborhood festival, we set up an educational stand to inform the public, and we even presented our findings and proposals to the mayor of our city. We advocated for reducing the production of synthetic sportswear and suggested more sustainable alternatives. As part of our methodology, students design and lead practical experiments and workshops for younger peers. We also joined the Pirates Against Plastic program and participated in a clean-up of the Llobregat riverbank to better understand how plastics move from land to sea. Additionally, we contacted sustainable textile companies like Guppyfriend and Cora Ball by writing letters in English. These companies produce tools to capture microplastics during laundry before they reach the water system and eventually the sea. This is a truly interdisciplinary project involving biology, technology, art, mathematics, social studies, physical education, and languages. Through real-world engagement, science, and communication, our students are becoming agents of change for a more sustainable future.

    • For Our Planet Award

      https://environment.ec.europa.eu/topics/nature-and-biodiv...
